verses.text: Jotham was twenty-five years old when he became king, and he reigned sixteen years in Jerusalem. His motherâ€™s name was Jerushah, the daughter of Zadok.
verses.comment: The verse closely follows the Hebrew text and mirrors the structure found in the parallel account in 2 Kings 15:33.

verses.text: He did what was right in the eyes of the Lord, just as his father Uzziah had done, but he did not enter the temple of the Lord. Yet the people continued in their corrupt ways.
verses.comment: Stays true to the original; 'corrupt ways' translates the Hebrew 'they acted corruptly.'

verses.text: He built the upper gate of the house of the Lord, and he did much construction on the wall of Ophel.
verses.comment: 'Ophel' is left untranslated as in most versions, referencing a specific part of Jerusalem.

verses.text: Moreover, he built cities in the hill country of Judah, and fortified places and towers on the wooded hills.
verses.comment: 'Wooded hills' renders the original term accurately, meaning 'forested places.'

verses.text: He fought with the king of the Ammonites and prevailed against them. That year the Ammonites gave him one hundred talents of silver, ten thousand cors of wheat, and ten thousand of barley. The Ammonites paid him this amount in the second and third years also.
verses.comment: 'Cors' is a unit of measure, left as is for accuracy (about 220 liters each).

verses.text: So Jotham became powerful because he ordered his ways before the Lord his God.
verses.comment: 'Ordered his ways' is literal Hebrew, meaning he set or established his conduct.

verses.text: Now the rest of the acts of Jotham, all his wars and his ways, they are written in the Book of the Kings of Israel and Judah.
verses.comment: 'Book of the Kings' refers to the lost records referenced throughout Chronicles and Kings.

verses.text: He was twenty-five years old when he began to reign, and he reigned sixteen years in Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Repeats the summary found in verse 1, exactly as in the source text.

verses.text: Jotham slept with his fathers, and they buried him in the city of David. His son Ahaz became king after him.
verses.comment: 'Slept with his fathers' is a literal rendering of the Hebrew euphemism for death.
